messageBody:
>So said Scott Stirling on 4/10/2003 --------------------
>> From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains@...]
>>
>> Guys, when it gets to the point where you're arguing over
>> definitions, stop. Definitions are arbitrary. You agree on the
>> concepts. Relax.
>
>The Java language only exists by virtue of its definition in the official
>language specification. Java's not very arbitrary. I think it was
>appropriate to refer (and defer) to the spec.

No argument. I think it a bit silly to dwell on it, though. Personal taste; no judgment implied.

>For the inner vs. nested distinction though, I think it's an unfortunate
>and
>too subtle choice of words in the spec. The distinction is exactly the
>sort
>of nit-picky thing that the Sun Java Programmer Certification exam looks
>for
>understanding of.

"static inner class" is merely a description of the implementation, whereas "nested class" reveals intent. The latter term is objectively better, but until the Java language changes how to write a nested class, it is equally accurate.

>For the original question, I think the major reason for avoiding the nested
>static class on any significant size project is practicality (concrete
>separation of concerns)...

Absolutely. Hear, hear and all that.

1. Not always one TestCase per class.
2. Nested TestCase classes are too intimate with the surrounding class.
3. More work than it needs to be to rip the tests out of the classes.
4. Looks weird (my opinion).
